text: RESEARCH

Ontology-driven relational data mapping for constructing a 
knowledge graph of porphyry copper deposits
Chengbin Wang1 · Liangquan Tan1,2 · Yuanjun Li1,3 · Mingguo Wang1,4 · Xiaogang Ma5 · Jianguo Chen1

Received: 29 November 2023 / Accepted: 7 April 2024
© The Author(s), under exclusive licence to Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2024

Abstract
Geoscience knowledge graph has become a popular topic in recent years. A series of studies have been reported to intro­
duce the construction and application of geoscience knowledge graphs from different views. The relational geoscience 
dataset with high knowledge density and data quality is an important digital heritage of geoscience. The relational dataset 
has not been taken seriously in the geoscience knowledge graph research. In this study, we proposed a quick method of 
building a geoscience knowledge graph using relational data mapping to triples. First, the use-case-driven method was 
applied to design the ontology of porphyry copper deposits. Second, the mapping rules were built based on the porphyry 
copper ontology. Third, the knowledge graph of the porphyry copper deposit was constructed based on relational data 
mapping and knowledge fusion. Based on the resulting knowledge graph, several exploratory cases were conducted to 
make knowledge reasoning and discovery. It is indicated that the solution proposed in this study is a fast batch-processing 
geoscience knowledge graph construction method. The experiences from this study can benefit the construction of knowl­
edge graphs in other geoscience disciplines and promote knowledge discovery.

Keywords  Relational data mapping · Geoscience knowledge graph · Porphyry copper deposit · Knowledge 
management · Knowledge discovery
Introduction

The knowledge graph is a triple-structured semantic net­
work. In the triple knowledge graph, the node represents 
the concept and entity object, and the edge represents the
Communicated by H. Babaie.
Chengbin Wang
wangchengbin@cug.edu.cn

semantic relationship between nodes (Ma 2022; Wang et al. 
2018b; Fensel et al. 2020). The knowledge graph is devel­
oped based on the semantic network, expert system, and 
ontology. Ideally, the knowledge graph can integrate hetero­
geneous geoscience big data and knowledge from multiple 
sources (Fensel et al. 2020; Wang et al. 2023a). The triple 
structure of the knowledge graph provides a powerful tool 
to handle the relational dataset and the unstructured geo­
logical literature.

In the era of big data and artificial intelligence, it has 
become a consensus between geologists and computer sci­
entists to utilize knowledge graph to harmonize geoscience 
big data and transform Earth science research for solving 
complex earth science problems (Zhou et al. 2021; Bergen 
et al. 2019; Gil et al. 2018; Normile 2019; Reichstein et al. 
2019; Wang et al. 2021). The EarthCube program aims to 
transform Earth science research by developing new-gen­
eration research tools (Koskela et al. 2017). One highlight 
is geological knowledge extraction from unstructured aca­
demic papers for serving earth science research (Husson et 
al. 2016; Zhang 2015; Kumar Gond et al. 2023; Peters et 
al. 2017). The Deep-time Digital Earth (Deep-time Digital

Earth), the first IUGS large scientific program, also wants 
to use the knowledge graph, big data, and artificial intel­
ligence techniques to transform Earth science (Zhou et al. 
2021; Normile 2019; Wang et al. 2021).

The literature review indicates that geoscience knowl­
edge graph research is preferred to the geoscience ontology 
and knowledge graph design based on the geoscience dis­
cipline knowledge and geological entity and semantic rela­
tions extraction from unstructured geoscience literature. A 
well-known case is the geologic time scale, a series of stud­
ies build the ontology and knowledge graph to uniform the 
different versions of geological time (Ma et al. 2020, 2022, 
2023; Cox and Richard 2015; Wang et al. 2018a). With the 
support of the Deep-time Digital Earth, a series of geosci­
ence knowledge graphs were constructed from the view of 
geoscience disciplines (e.g., Parsons et al. 2023; Chen et al. 
2023; Yu et al. 2023; Xu et al. 2023; Wang et al. 2023c; Hu 
et al. 2023a, b; Tang et al. 2023), which greatly promoted 
the research and development of knowledge graph in the 
field of geosciences. Besides, the deep learning and natu­
ral language processing methods are used in the geologi­
cal entities and their semantic relations extraction from the 
unstructured geological documents (e.g., Qiu et al. 2019a, 
b, 2023a, b; Wang et al. 2023b; Enkhsaikhan 2021; Fan et 
al. 2019; Lv et al. 2022; Li et al. 2021; Zhou et al. 2020; 
Zhu et al. 2017). These works have improved the utilization 
of unstructured geological datasets and promoted the con­
struction and application of geoscience knowledge graphs, 
absorbing geological documents as a knowledge source for 
the construction of geoscience knowledge graphs.

The geoscience knowledge graph has become a popu­
lar point in geoinformatics. It benefits data and knowledge 
management and data-driven geoscience research. The 
existing relational geoscience database is an important digi­
tal heritage. Compared with unstructured geoscience litera­
ture, relational geoscience databases have higher knowledge 
density and data quality. However, in the process of geosci­
ence knowledge graph construction, the relational dataset 
is a neglected knowledge source, and few works have been 
reported in recent years. In this study, we selected porphyry 
copper deposits as a case study to facilitate the fast con­
struction of a knowledge graph of porphyry copper deposits 
using relational data mapping method driven by the ontol­
ogy model.
Methods and datasets

Use-case-driven ontology construction of porphyry 
copper deposits

The knowledge graph is organized as triples, including 
entities and their semantic links. A relational database is 
a collection of tables presented as rows and columns. The 
relational database organizes the data by using the rela­
tionship, constraint, and schema. The relational database is 
schema-dependent and implicit and has the drawbacks of the 
semantic relationship between entities. Moreover, schema-
first structure constraints make establishing links between 
different databases impossible. Using the triple structure, 
the knowledge graph with strong semantics is suitable for 
data management. The advantage of logical reasoning in the 
knowledge graph also shows excellent potential for intel­
ligent decisions in geosciences.

Some studies have proven that relational data could be 
transformed into RDF-based graph data (Wang et al. 2023a; 
Cerans and Būmans 2015; Devi et al. 2018a; Chhaya et al. 
2016). In the mineral deposit domain, how to design the 
rules guiding the transformation from relational data to 
RDF-based data becomes a fundamental issue that needs to 
be addressed. The ontology is the formal specification of 
the shared conceptualization and is usually regarded as a 
knowledge graph schema layer. A domain ontology con­
tains domain core vocabulary representing the domain enti­
ties and their semantic relationships. Therefore, the domain 
ontology model can be used to guide the data mapping from 
relational data to RDF-based data.

This study designed a porphyry copper deposit ontology 
using the use-case-driven method (Wang et al. 2023a, b) that 
is a hybrid method combining the top-down and bottom-
up methods. Based on the domain knowledge of porphyry 
copper deposits and geological documents associated with 
the porphyry copper deposit, firstly, we choose a porphyry 
copper deposit (e.g., Dexing porphyry copper deposits) as a 
case study and enumerate all the entity instances recorded 
in the geological documents. Secondly, domain knowledge 
was used to define the entity classes derived from instances 
and hierarchical semantic relations. In this way, an ontology 
representing the core knowledge of the porphyry copper 
deposit was built.
Data mapping rules

According to the porphyry copper deposit ontology, the 
mapping from relational data to the knowledge graph was 
carried out on the D2RQ platform based on the custom­
ized mapping rules. The D2RQ includes mapping language, 
engine, and server. It supports the mapping standards of

direct mapping and R2RML released by W3C (Michel et 
al. 2013; Devi et al. 2018b). The relational data mapping 
depends on two objects ClassMap and PropertyBridge. The 
ClassMap corresponds to the entity classes and defines how 
entity instances from the relational database are identified. 
PropertyBridge is related to a database column and used to 
attach the property to the entity produced by ClassMap1.

The mapping rules from relational database schema to 
ontology are defined by the declarative D2RQ mapping 
language and written in Turtle syntax. According to the 
D2RQ mapping syntax, in the mapping progress, the target 
entity (e.g., relational data sources, entity unique identifier, 
and label) is first built in the mapping rule. The semantic 
links are then created using PropertyBridge, including the 
definition of the property class, head entity, tail entity, and 
their labels (Fig. 1). In the Fig. 1, the blocks respectively 
define the namespace, data source, and setting parameters

Fig. 1  The mapping rules of porphyry copper deposits. The blocks respectively define the namespace, data source, and setting parameters of sub­
ject and PropertyBridge
1  http://d2rq.org/d2rq-language#propertybridge.

of subject and PropertyBridge. For instance, As depicted 
in Fig. 1, besides the definition of the database connection, 
we define the mapping of mineral deposit names from rela­
tional data to the triple structure. In this way, all the map­
ping rules derived from the ontology model can be encoded 
for relational data mapping of porphyry copper deposits and 
the fast construction of a domain knowledge graph.
Workflow of mapping relational data to graph data

This study proposed a workflow to map relational data to 
graph data and build a knowledge graph of porphyry copper 
deposits. The workflow was divided into three parts: con­
structing porphyry copper deposit ontology, designing the 
mapping rule, and using SQL (Structured Query Language) 
query from porphyry copper deposits relational data for rela­
tional data mapping. The porphyry copper deposit ontology

defines the geological entities and their semantic links in 
the knowledge graph of porphyry copper deposits and pro­
vides a roadmap for data mapping. Mapping rules clarify 
the constraints of input from relational data and output of 
graph-structured data. The SQL query is the relational data 
preprocessing for extracting data as head and tail entities of 
a triple. The data mapping is the last step for producing the 
graph-structured data encoded using N-triples (Fig. 2). In 
this way, the porphyry copper deposit knowledge graph can 
be built by combining the N-triples for a unified knowledge 
graph (Wang et al. 2023a).
Datasets

The relational dataset used in this study is from the open 
database of the USGS global porphyry copper deposit2. 
The database records detailed information (e.g., location, 
geological setting, age, wall rock, ore body, alteration, ore 
grade, tonnage, and so on) of more than 690 global porphyry 
copper deposits. The database gives a general classification 
based on the geological setting and mineralogy. Geographic 
coordinate information is also available for data sharing 
and interaction in the GIS platform. Although the database 
is structured, some records are semi-structured, such as 
the rock types and the mineral association. The semantic 
segmentation for the semi-structured records based on the 
separator is necessary for further mapping from relational to 
graph-structured data.
Fig. 2  The workflow showing the main steps for ontology-driven data mapping from relational data to triples
2  https://mrdata.usgs.gov/porcu/.
Results
Porphyry copper deposit ontology

The ontology of the porphyry copper deposit provides a 
framework for constructing a knowledge graph. In the por­
phyry copper deposit ontology model, there are 24 entity 
classes associated with the porphyry copper deposit (Fig. 3). 
The entity classes related to the knowledge portrait of a 
mineral deposit contain the core metallogenic information 
from PCD: Element in the micro-scale to PCD: Geologi­
calSetting on the regional scale. The presence and combina­
tion of these entity classes can give a lively description of a 
mineral deposit. The representation between two entities is 
the semantic relations. In the ontology of porphyry copper 
deposit, the semantic relations are categorized into isCon­
trolledBy, isRelatedTo, hasElement, hasMinerals, hasAlter­
ation, hasFluidType, isLocatedIn, isFormedIn, isStudiedBy 
and the OWL’s datatype property (Wang et al. 2023a, b). In 
this study, our works prefer the geological entities and their 
semantic relations (Fig. 3).

These semantic relations listed in this paper are the sum­
marized and concise results from geological literature. In the 
geological documents, the location description of mineral 
deposits has different forms of natural language sentences. 
It can express the location information from different views, 
such as geography and geological setting. In the ontology 
of porphyry copper deposits, we treat them as the range and 
domain constraint. For the semantic relations of isLocate­
dIn, the PCD: MineralDeposit is listed in the domain, and 
the range of this semantic relation can be PCD: Geological­
Setting or PCD: Location.

Fig. 3  A simplified diagram representing the porphyry copper deposit ontology model. The core is the use case. The corresponding entities and 
semantic relations are derived from it
Mapping results of porphyry copper deposits

The ontology of porphyry copper deposit provides a detailed 
framework of entity and semantic link classes. It is a pio­
neer process for encoding the mapping rules from relational 
dataset to graph-structured data. The ontology also endows 
strong semantic information for the relational dataset, which 
benefits the human-machine reading and understanding of 
the geoscience knowledge records. Based on the porphyry 
copper database, each geological entity was given a unique 
ID. The geological entity pairs are extracted from the data­
base and stored in a relational sheet. These preprocessing

steps are manually processed and then imported into the 
relational database or through the SQL-generated views of 
the relational data into a view.

In this study, we obtained 24,107 geological entities 
(Table 1) that are defined in the ontology and 32,155 records 
of triple Triple-RDF records encoded using N-Triples format 
(Fig. 4). Every line includes three angle brackets represent­
ing the head entity, semantic relation, and tail entity, respec­
tively. The triple individuals mapped from the relational 
dataset are isolated and don’t form a semantic network. 
The mapping result has some geological entities that appear 
repeatedly. The triple fusion was carried out to combine the

triple individuals together and remove semantic ambiguity 
to build a knowledge graph of porphyry copper deposits. 
Based on the relational data mapping and data fusion, a 
knowledge graph including 2, 907 geological entities and 
19, 050 semantic relations were constructed (Table 2).

Application of the porphyry copper deposit 
knowledge graph

The porphyry copper deposit knowledge graph after knowl­
edge fusion was stored and visualized using the Neo4J plat­
form. The knowledge graph contains the knowledge of the 
porphyry copper deposits. It provides a human-machine 
knowledge base of porphyry copper deposit for knowl­
edge query, retrieval, and knowledge discovery. Based on 
the knowledge graph, several case studies of knowledge 
exploration analysis were carried out to verify the use of the 
knowledge graph.

In studying mineral deposit models and mineral resources 
exploration, geologists usually need to understand the min­
eral deposit by reading a series of geological documents. 
It is a high labor-cost and low efficiency. In this study, the 
knowledge graph of porphyry copper deposit provides a 
quick way to obtain the knowledge graph related to a por­
phyry copper deposit. For instance, we can use the query 
statement encoded in Cypher language (Fig. 5A) to retrieve

the knowledge related to the Agua Rica porphyry copper 
deposits. The query result is shown in the form of a net­
work that includes nodes and their links. Visualizing query 
results is an interactive way that users can click and drag 
to discover more detailed knowledge. The visualization of 
the query (Fig. 5B) shows the core knowledge related to the 
Agua Rica porphyry copper deposits. The nodes of geologi­
cal entities are linked by the line with semantic information 
between two geological entities.

The knowledge graph of porphyry copper deposits also 
can promote knowledge discoveries. The analogy is a basic 
principle in mineral exploration. Similar mineral deposits 
have similar characteristics, and similar mineral prospect­
ing methods are used to find them. This study used Jaccard 
similarity to find porphyry copper deposits similar to the 
Auga Rica deposit. The Jaccard similarity is defined as the 
ratio of the size of the intersection of A and B to the size of 
the union of A and B (Jaccard 1912). The ten most simi­
lar porphyry copper deposits to the Auga Rica deposit are 
shown in Table 3.

These ten porphyry copper entity pairs and their asso­
ciated magmatic rock entities queried from the knowledge 
graph are shown in Fig. 6. Compared with Table 3, the graph 
(Fig. 6) represents a direct and visual repression between 
mineral deposits, magmatic rocks, and their relations. It is 
also indicated that the magmatic rocks of granite, andesite,

the yellow-brown nodes represent magma rock nodes

basalt, tuff, rhyolite porphyry, and andesite have closer links 
with the ten porphyry copper deposits. The rock types, such 
as gabbro, tonalite, and rhyolite, have weak links with the 
porphyry copper deposit and are distributed on the edge of 
the graph. This discovery illustrates that the mineralization 
of porphyry deposits has similar mineralization specificity 
to rock bodies.
Discussion

The relational database is an important infrastructure that 
stores structured data and knowledge. The existing rela­
tional geoscience database is an important digital heri­
tage. This study shows a quick solution for constructing

a knowledge graph that employs the relational data map­
ping method to map the relational data to the triple knowl­
edge graph. The experiences from this study indicate that 
the workflow proposed in this study is a useful and easy-
to-operate method. In machine learning-based natural lan­
guage processing methods, building a training corpus and 
a well-performing training model is a very time-consuming 
task. Mapping rule creation in relational data mapping is a 
lightweight task. Compared with natural language process­
ing methods to build knowledge graphs, this method makes 
full use of existing databases and can reduce computing 
power and labor costs. The knowledge extracted from rela­
tional databases can also fed back to the knowledge graph 
construction using natural language processing and deep 
learning methods.

In this study, the ontology of porphyry copper deposit 
is the top framework that defines the classes of geological 
entities and their semantic relations. It is directional guid­
ance to geoscience relational data mapping for construct­
ing the knowledge graph and building a bridge between 
database records and triples. However, there is a dispute 
over distinguishing attributes from geological entities dur­
ing ontology construction. For example, the geochemical 
element is a point of controversy. From the view of rock, 
geochemical elements can be regarded as the property of 
rock. However, from a disciplinary perspective, geochemi­
cal elements exist objectively. After a careful discussion, we 
reached an agreement that a geochemical element is defined 
as the geological entity in this study. We conclude an experi­
ence that ontology development should be oriented to appli­
cation scenarios.

The main purpose of this study is to use relational data 
mapping to build a knowledge graph defined by an ontol­
ogy of porphyry copper deposits. The ontology designed a 
detailed definition that has a series of geological entities and 
their semantic links. In the mapping results, there are some 
missing values in Table 2. Although the existing database 
plays an important role in constructing a knowledge graph, 
the limited number of attributes of the database cannot 
cover the data and knowledge requirement for a knowledge 
graph. In addition to relational data, unstructured text data 
that requires natural language processing is another impor­
tant source of knowledge for improving and expanding a 
knowledge graph. Therefore, building a geoscience knowl­
edge graph requires the joint use of relational and unstruc­
tured data.

The application cases of the porphyry copper knowledge 
graph shown in the study prove the powerful performance in 
knowledge management and knowledge discoveries. With 
the expansion of the number of knowledge nodes in the por­
phyry copper deposit knowledge graph, it has huge potential 
in knowledge mining and knowledge discovery in this field. 
Besides, integrating with other knowledge graphs and mak­
ing a joint knowledge discovery are important development 
directions for understanding the Earth’s evolution and min­
eral deposit model.
Conclusions

In recent years, geologists and computer scientists have 
devoted a lot of enthusiasm to the geoscience knowledge 
graph. In this study, we proposed a solution mapping rela­
tional geoscience database to build the knowledge graph 
of porphyry copper deposits. Based on this study, the fol­
lowing conclusion can be drawn: (1) the relational data­
set in geoscience is an important digital heritage, and full

utilization of relational data can quickly construct a geosci­
ence knowledge graph. (2) Geoscience ontology is the top 
design of a knowledge graph. Building geoscience ontology 
should be orientated to the scenarios. (3) The knowledge 
graph can improve geoscience knowledge management 
and promote knowledge queries and new knowledge dis­
coveries. (4) Data mapping to build a knowledge graph is a 
preliminary work. It is necessary to combine the reorganiza­
tion of geological entities and their semantic relations from 
unstructured geoscience literature using natural language 
processing and deep learning methods to construct a whole 
knowledge graph.

Author contributions  ChengbinWang: writing-original draft, concep­
tualization, data validation, writing-review and editing, project admin­
istration, funding acquisition. Liangquan Tan: building the mapping 
rules. Yuanjun Li: knowledge graph visualization and application. 
Mingguo Wang: writing-review and editing. Xiaogang Ma: writing-
review and editing, data validation. Jianguo Chen: funding acquisition, 
data validation, writing-review, and editing.

obtained from US Geological Survey (https://mrdata.usgs.gov/porcu/). 
The file of mapping rules is available on GitHub at https://github.com/
wangcug/DataMapping.

https://github.com/wangcug/DataMapping.
